title: Protocol for determining zinc-dependent β cell-selective small-molecule delivery in mouse pancreas
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Assess islet Zn2+ chelation by microscopy
Timing: 1–2 days per compound
This competition assay with TSQ is a readily accessible experimental system to establish the capacity of small molecules to chelate Zn2+ in islets. TPEN, an exceptionally strong Zn2+ chelator, serves as a positive control for Zn2+ competition.
Prepare frozen mouse pancreas sections.
Label plastic blocks and fill with OCT at 20°C–24°C.
Note: Avoid introducing air bubbles.
Have dry ice ready in an insulated container.
Dissect out mouse pancreas.
Perform euthanasia by anesthetizing a mouse with isoflurane overdose, then cervical dislocation.
Note: Humanely sacrifice mice under appropriate conditions to minimize pain and distress.
Open the body cavity and cut the pancreas away from the spleen and duodenum.
Critical: Take special care to include the islet rich pancreatic tail in the dissection.
Place pancreas in OCT.
Use forceps to shape the pancreas into a dense ball.
Place pancreas in middle of OCT and press the pancreas toward the center of the OCT so it is fully submerged.
Place mold on dry ice.
Critical: Do not fix the tissue at any stage, as TSQ/Zn2+ staining will be removed.
Pause Point: Transfer to −80°C for storage or continue to tissue sectioning.
Note: Sections can be stored at −80°C for at least 12 months without loss in quality.
Cut frozen sections.
Have clear slides at 20°C–24°C next to a cryostat for section mounting and dry ice available for storing completed slides.
Note: Use a fresh blade for the best results.
Set cryostat blade to cut 10 μm sections, mount frozen block in cryostat, and cut into the block until the pancreas is included on sections.
Place intact pancreatic sections on (+)-charged slides. Place as many as two sections/slide.

Store sections on dry ice while cutting, or place directly at −80°C.
Prepare at least 8 sections for testing individual compounds, and at least 2 sections for control treatments.
Pause Point: Either transfer to −80°C for storage or continue to staining.
Conduct competition assays with experimental compounds and TSQ (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]A).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/365-Fig1.jpg
Figure 1. Assessment of islet Zn2+ chelation by fluorescence microscopy
(A) Experimental workflow consists of treatment of pancreatic frozen sections with TSQ, followed by treatment with a competing chelator, and fluorescent imaging.
(B) Representative imaging results of TSQ-treated sections, without and with TPEN as a competing chelator. Islets are highlighted (yellow).
(C) Representative result of islet section treated without and with TPEN, with constant TSQ (10 μM). Relative fluorescence is defined as the normalized ratio of islet TSQ fluorescence to exocrine TSQ fluorescence, where sections treated with TSQ alone are 100% and sections treated with TSQ and TPEN are 0%. Data are represented as means ± SD.
Prepare staining solutions.
Prepare phosphate-buffered saline (PBS) (37 mM NaCl, 2.7 mM KCl, 10 mM Na2HPO4, 1.8 mM KH2PO4, pH 7.4).
Prepare DCS-1 solution by diluting Nuclear Green (DCS-1) in PBS at 1 μM final concentration.
Prepare TSQ staining solution by diluting TSQ to 10 μM in DCS-1 staining solution. Make at least 500 μL per compound to be tested.
Use DCS-1 solution to make compound dilutions for experimental testing. For compounds without known chelating activity, start by testing a single concentration (500 μM or 1 mM). Test experimental compounds at a range of concentrations from 500 μM to 1 μM.
Note: Approximately 50 μL of diluted compound is needed per experimental concentration.
As a positive control, dilute TPEN to 500 μM in DCS-1 solution. In parallel, make a vehicle control by making a 5% solution of DMSO in DSC-1 solution.

Stain tissue sections.
Bring section to 20°C–24°C, wash by dipping the section in PBS, and carefully dry off extra liquid using a lint-free wipe.
Demarcate pancreas using a hydrophobic marker in a small circle.
Add the TSQ-containing staining solution (50 μL) to the section and incubate 5 min, covered with aluminum foil.
Remove solution with a pipette without disturbing tissue.
Pipette the experimental or control compound solution (50 μL) onto the TSQ-stained section and incubate 5 min, covered with aluminum foil.
Remove solution and replace with 100 μL PBS per tissue sample.
Determine islet TSQ fluorescence (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]B).
Place slides on a fluorescent microscope at 10–20× magnification.
Find islets by locating areas with sparse nuclei as seen in the green channel (see Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]B).
Note: Green fluorescence displays DCS-1 staining of nuclei and allows islets to be located, whereas blue fluorescence reflects the presence of Zn2+-TSQ complex.
Obtain microscope images to capture green (Excitation 503 nm, Emission 526 nm) and blue fluorescence (Excitation 370 nm, Emission 495 nm).
Note: TPEN-treated sections should have similar TSQ fluorescence in islet and non-islet tissues; alternatively, DMSO-treated sections should exhibit robust islet TSQ fluorescence relative to non-islet pancreatic tissue.
Capture at least 3 images at 20× magnification of different islets on every section.
Repeat the above staining protocol for every experimental compound concentration.
Critical: The time duration from initiating section TSQ staining until image capture should not exceed 10 min.
Pause Point: Additional compound dilutions may be evaluated on freshly thawed sections as convenient.
Quantify and plot islet fluorescence (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]C).
Use Photoshop (Adobe) or equivalent software to analyze blue/green fluorescent images.
Identify islets in the green channel and demarcate the areas of interest using the elliptical marquee tool.

Record the median fluorescent intensity of the identified region(s) in the blue channel. This value reflects islet fluorescence.
Move the marquee tool, without changing its size or shape, to a non-islet area and record blue median fluorescence.
Repeat for all islets in all images.
Calculate the ratio of islet to exocrine median fluorescence in the blue (TSQ) channel for all islets imaged.
Normalize islet/exocrine fluorescence ratio to 0% (TPEN-treated) and 100% (DMSO-treated) following the below formula: imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/365-Si1.jpg
Plot the normalized fluorescence according to experimental compound treatment concentration.
Using Prism (GraphPad) or equivalent software, fit the dilution data to a 4-parameter inhibition curve to obtain the 4 parameter values of Top, Bottom, IC50, and nH.
Note: IC50 and nH indicate strength of chelator’s affinity for Zn2+ in an islet context.
Assess islet accumulation of compounds by LC-MS/MS
Timing: 3 days
This step measures zinc-dependent accumulation of Zn2+-binding compounds in islets (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/365-Fig2.jpg
Figure 2. Assessment of islet accumulation of compounds by LC-MS/MS
(A) Experimental workflow includes incubation of isolated islets or exocrine pancreas with chelator, followed by quantification by LC-MS/MS.
(B) Representative raw data for standard concentrations of TSQ.
(C) Representative calibration curve for TSQ standards shown in (B).
(D) Representative peaks and quantification for islets treated with TSQ, without and with TPEN.
Obtain islets and exocrine pancreas from mice.
Euthanize mice by isoflurane overdose followed by cervical dislocation.
Note: Humanely sacrifice mice under appropriate conditions to minimize pain and distress.
Isolate islets from pancreata using bile duct-based collagenase A perfusion followed by tissue extraction and histopaque centrifugation (Gotoh et al., 1985[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib7]; Zhao et al., 2016[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib15]).
Collect and suspend isolated islets in low glucose DMEM with 1× penicillin-streptomycin and 10% fetal bovine serum.

Collect and suspend pelleted exocrine tissue in low glucose DMEM with 1× penicillin-streptomycin and 10% fetal bovine serum.
Note: Exocrine tissue must be used within 3 h of isolation. Islets can be used immediately or rested 16 h in medium at 37°C in a tissue culture incubator.
Note: Keep pelleted exocrine tissue following histopaque centrifugation cold on ice (0°C) during the islet extraction process.
Quantify protein in islets and exocrine tissue.
Take an aliquot of handpicked islets ( ≥ 40 islets) and of exocrine tissue, spin down and resuspend in PBS, and lyse by at least 3 freeze/thaw cycles.
Use a fraction of the collected tissues to quantify the total islet and exocrine protein using the DC Protein Assay (Bio-Rad) or an equivalent assay.
Use at least 1 μg of islet or exocrine protein per experimental condition.
Note: Islet and exocrine tissues should be kept intact for the drug accumulation assay, i.e., discrete aliquots are used for protein concentration determination.
Perform accumulation assay (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]A).
Split islet and exocrine tissue into PCR tubes at equivalent protein concentrations, at 0.1–0.5 μg protein/μL. Dilute to 10 μL (i.e., 1–5 μg) per condition.
Add TPEN (1 mM final concentration) or vehicle (DMSO) to conditions.
Incubate 5 min in thermal cycler at 37°C.
Add test compounds in media (recommended concentration of 10 μM).
Perform experiment in at least quadruplicate, preferably n=6–12.
Include the addition of a non-chelating compound [10 μM] in every condition (e.g., the scaffold on which the bi-functional compound is based) for normalizing zinc-dependent drug accumulation (see below, step 7h).
Include TSQ (10 μM)-treated islets and exocrine tissue as a positive control.
Incubate islets and exocrine tissue in a thermal cycler for 30 min at 37°C.
Place samples on ice (0°C).

Rapidly (within 20 s) add 50 μL PBS, spin down (<20 s, ≤2,000 × g), take off PBS, and repeat.
After second wash, suspend tissues in 20 μL PBS total and freeze at −20°C.
Pause Point: Either continue onto quantification or place in freezer. Samples may be stored for at least 4 weeks without compromising quality.
Quantification by LC-MS/MS (Troubleshooting[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting]) (Figures 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]B and 2C)
Note: LC-MS/MS conditions using different mobile phases, extraction procedures, or liquid chromatography gradients may be used, as long as the compound(s) of interest efficiently elute from the column and display linearity of peak area vs. concentration.
Prepare a calibration curve with compounds of interest from 50 μM down to 1 nM in MeOH, water, MeCN, or other LC-MS/MS compatible solvent.
Note: Do not use DMSO as solvent.
Include at least two compound concentration points per order of magnitude.
Prepare standards (50–100 μM) of each individual analyte for method development.
Establish a multi-reaction monitoring method for each compound.
Dilute islet and exocrine pancreas assay samples, as well as all standards in calibration curve, 1:2 in 50% MeCN/50% water with 0.1% formic acid.
Centrifuge all samples and place supernatant free of particulate into LC-MS/MS plates or vials.
If particulate remains, adjust MeCN/water mix and/or dilute further.
Run standard curves and samples over LC-MS/MS using a gradient of MeCN and water.
Start with a gradient of 95% water→40% water→50% water→95% water over 4–6 min.
If analyte peaks appear at the beginning (initial 30 s) or end (final 30 s) of the elution, adjust gradient or change solvents.
Quantify each analyte peak according to its peak area in the standard curve (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]D).
Plot compound accumulation (nmol/g protein) and ratio to non-chelator in sample for islets and exocrine tissue. Use the formulas imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/365-Si2.jpg imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/365-Si3.jpg

Note: Zn2+-dependent accumulation is evidenced by islet-selective, TPEN-sensitive compound accumulation. TSQ should exhibit a 2–4-fold excess accumulation in islets versus exocrine tissue that is ablated by TPEN.
Assess β cell-selective replication
Timing: 5 days
This step describes a method for assessing in vitro compound-stimulated β cell and non-β cell replication induction, providing a compound-specific β cell selectivity index (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]A).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/365-Fig3.jpg
Figure 3. Assessment of β cell-selective replication
(A) Experimental workflow involves islet isolation, dispersal to single cells by trypsinization, compound treatment and incubation, fixing and antibody staining, and quantification of replication by ArrayScan methodology.
(B) Representative results for a control non-chelating and chelating replication compound, with β cell replication signified by yellow arrows, and non-β cell replication signified by white arrows.
Note: Alternative methods for assessing β cell replication exist and include, but are not limited to, immunofluorescent imaging of intact islets (Kong et al., 2018[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib9]) or FACS-based replication analysis (Carballar et al., 2017[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib4]). To assess cellular replication, alternative markers to Ki-67 such as BrDU (Lindberg et al., 2005[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib11]) or EDU (Salic and Mitchison, 2008[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib12]) may be used.
Obtain islets from rats.
Obtain Sprague-Dawley (250 g) rats.
Note: Other rat strains are likely acceptable. Rat islets have higher basal and compound-induced replication than mouse or human islets, facilitating determination of compound efficacy.
Euthanize rats by isoflurane overdose and cervical dislocation.
Note: Humanely sacrifice rats under appropriate conditions to minimize pain and distress.
Isolate islets from pancreata using bile duct-based collagenase A perfusion followed by tissue extraction and histopaque centrifugation as described in detail (Gotoh et al., 1985[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib7]; Zhao et al., 2016[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib15]).
Collect and suspend isolated islets in low glucose DMEM with 1× penicillin-streptomycin and 10% fetal bovine serum and culture in a tissue culture incubator (12–16 h).

On the day of islet isolation, treat 384-well black fluorescence cell culture plates with 804-G cell conditioned medium (Preparing conditioned media) with 50 μL per well. Place plates in a cell culture incubator (37°C) 12–16 h.
Disperse islets into single cells.
Collect islets in a 50 mL conical tube and centrifuge at 197 × g for 5 min.
Warm Trypsin-EDTA and low glucose DMEM with 10% FBS and 1× penicillin-streptomycin to 37°C.
Carefully remove supernatant using a 1 mL aspirating pipet with a 200 μL pipet tip on the end.
Wash cells with PBS (30 mL), centrifuge at 197 × g for 5 min.
Again, carefully remove supernatant as in step 9c. Suspend the islet pellet in pre-warmed Trypsin-EDTA (250 μL per rat) and place at 37°C for 5 min.
Pipet up and down with a 1,000 μL pipet 25 times, then place at 37°C for another 5 min.
Pipet up and down with a 200 μL pipet 30 times and place at 37°C for an additional 5 min.
Pipet up and down with a 200 μL pipet 30 times.
If visible chunks of islets remain, add more trypsin and repeat steps 9e–9h.
Place digested islets on ice and count a 1:10 dilution (e.g., 1 μL of islets in 9 μL media) using a hemocytometer.
Repeat count for precision using a fresh 1:10 dilution of digested islets.
The presence of aggregated cells indicates insufficient trypsin digestion; repeat (9h) as necessary.
Calculate the number of wells that can be plated. The density must be 25,000–28,000 cells/well for optimal results. For example, if 1,000,000 cells are counted, a maximum of 40 wells can be used.
Dilute the trypsinized cells in low glucose DMEM with 10% FBS and 1× penicillin-streptomycin for a final volume of 60 μL/well.

Plate the cells in the coated 384-well cell culture plates from step 8e.
Note: Avoid the four wells at each edge of the plate to avoid poorly understood “edge-effects” on assay reproducibility.
Culture cells for 48 h at 37°C to allow attachment.
Note: At this point cells should be flattened and in small cell clusters throughout the well, as assessed under a microscope. This process has been visualized in a previously published step-by-step protocol (Zhao et al., 2016[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib15]).
Treat cells
Prepare concentrated stock solutions ([10 mM] in DMSO) of experimental compounds. Include a positive control replication-inducing compound such as GNF-4877 (>150 nM) or OTS-167 (2–20 nM).
Prepare treatment solutions by diluting compounds in media to 3× the desired final concentration.
Include at least 6 DMSO-treated wells to establish a baseline replication rate.
Prior to drug treatment, perform a partial media exchange by adding 50 μL per well and then removing 70 μL (40 μL final volume).
Treat cells with 20 μL of the prepared β cell replication-stimulating compound or DMSO solutions (final volume 60 μL), and incubate at 37°C for 48–72 h.
Fix and stain cells
After incubation, remove culture media by inverting the tissue culture plate and forcefully decanting.
Fix cells using 8% PFA (60 μL/well) for 20 min.
Replace PFA with PBS (100 μL/well).
Pause Point: Plates may be kept at 4°C for up to 2 weeks without substantial loss in staining quality.
Freshly prepare antigen retrieval solution by diluting 0.15 M sodium citrate pH 6.0 at a 1:20 dilution in formamide.
Decant PBS solution.
Immediately add antigen retrieval solution (70 μL/well) and heat at 70°C for 45 min.
Use a water bath with just enough water to cover skirt of plate without submerging it.

Place a heavy object, such as a full bottle, atop the plate to prevent bowing/deformation of the tissue culture plate during heating.
Remove from water bath and allow the plate to cool (15 min at 20°C–24°C).
Wash wells with PBS twice (100 μL/well).
Apply blocking solution (6.25% donkey serum, 0.3% Tx-100 in PBS; 50 μL/well) for 30 min at 20°C–24°C.
Prepare antibody dilution solution by diluting blocking solution 1:5 in PBS.
Decant blocking solution and add primary antibodies (1:100 anti-PDX-1 (goat, R&D systems), 1:200 anti-Ki-67 (mouse, BD), 1:300 anti-insulin (rabbit, Cell Signaling)) in antibody dilution solution (40–50 μL/well).
Incubate (12–16 h) at 4°C.
Decant primary antibody solution, wash twice with PBS (100 μL/well).
Add secondary antibodies (Cy5, goat; Rhodamine Red, rabbit; AF488, mouse; Jackson ImmunoResearch, all 1:200) in antibody dilution solution (40–50 μL/well).
Note: Use of TRITC-conjugated antibodies is not recommended because they may exhibit green channel fluorescence.
Cover the plate with aluminum foil and incubate 1 h at 20°C–24°C.
Wash twice with PBS (100 μL/well) and treat with Hoechst 33342 [4 μM] staining solution (50 μL/well) for 20 min.
Remove Hoechst staining solution and replace with 100 μL PBS.
Pause Point: Aluminum foil covered plates may be stored at 4°C for up to 4 weeks without substantially reducing image quality.
Image using ArrayScan (Thermo Fisher) (Annes et al., 2012[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib3]; Zhao et al., 2016[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib15]) or other high-content cell-scanning microscope (Troubleshooting[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting]).
Define a four-color protocol to image Hoechst, Ki-67, PDX-1, and insulin staining.
Using a test well (positive control) determine optimal focus and exposure times for the plate.
Note: If only three colors are available, use either PDX-1 or insulin instead of both.
Define parameters to exclude fibroblasts.
Select cells of interest by applying a nuclear (Hoechst) staining intensity threshold.

Apply a maximum value for nuclear size since islet endocrine cells have smaller nuclei than fibroblasts.
Define replication events by the presence of Ki-67-positive staining in β cells or non-β cells.
Define replication events based on Ki-67 staining intensity.
Define β cell events based on insulin and/or PDX-1 co-staining.
Acquire images (70 fields/well) and quantify the frequency of replication events (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]B).
Determine the average basal (DMSO-treated) β cell and non-β cell replication rates with the following formulas imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/365-Si4.jpg imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/365-Si5.jpg
Note: Islets from Sprague-Dawley rats of this size typically exhibit a basal β cell replication rate of 0.5%–2.0%.
Determine the compound-induced replication rates using the same calculations for both β cell and non-β cell populations as described in 13a.
Note: The minimal effective concentration stimulated by a small molecule can be obtained by comparing individual compound-treated replication rates to the basal replication rate using the pairwise Student’s t test.
Determine the fold replication induced by each treatment by dividing the induced replication rate by the average basal replication rate imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/365-Si6.jpg imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/365-Si7.jpg
Determine selectivity ratio by dividing the fold replication induced in β cells by the fold replication induced in non β cells using the formula imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/365-Si8.jpg
